results.title: Billy's Hollywood screen kiss
results.creator_credit: Revolutionary Eye, David Moseley and Tommy O'Haver
results.brief_description: Tommy O’Haver’s upbeat romantic comedy is an affectionate tribute to gay men’s affiliation and love affair with the movies and the larger than life screen passions which subsequently inform and delude romantic expectations. Aspiring photographer Billy Coller (Sean. P Hayes) is down on his luck financially and romantically. His unfortunate habit of falling for straight guys lands heterosexual model Gabriel (Brad Rowe) into his path. When Billy enlists his new found lust object into posing for a series of queer themed photos aping classic screen kisses, sexual confusion ensues. Cast includes Paul Bartel, Holly Woodlawn, Richard Ganoung and Meredith Scott Lynn.

results.title: Bill and Ted's excellent adventure
results.creator_credit: Interscope communications, Scott Kroopf, Michael S Murphey, Joel Soisson and Stephen Herek
results.brief_description: Bill (Alex Winter) and Ted (Keanu Reeves) are two teenagers who are on the verge of flunking out of high school. Acing an oral history assignment the next day is all that will spare the friends from being separated, as Ted’s draconian father is on the cusp of shipping Ted off to academy school. From the future, arrives Rufus (George Carlin), in a time travelling phone box. His mission is to give Bill and Ted the means to learn history in one night enabling them to pass their oral test. Bill and Ted rise to the challenge and ride the phone box to various times past, picking up figures of historical significance that will assist them with their presentation. Bill and Ted collect Napoleon, Joan of Arc, Socrates, Sigmund Freud, Billy the Kid and Genghis Khan. Co-written by Ed Solomon (Men in black, Charlie’s angels), “Bill and Ted’s excellent adventure”, is an example of “dude” teen humour, continued with the likes of “Wayne’s world”. Reeves and Winter are effective as the hapless dudes, equipped with their own language and logic, and a shared love of Van Halen. Directed by Stephen Herek (Mr Holland’s opus, Rock Star, Life or something like it).

results.title: Bill and Coo
results.creator_credit: Republic Pictures Corporation, Ken Murray and Dean Riesner
results.brief_description: The trials and tribulations of the inhabitants of Chirpendale are enacted entirely by birds, mostly wearing hats and neckties. An eccentricity which won its creator, Ken Murray, a special academy award.

results.title: Biggie and Tupac
results.creator_credit: Lafayette Films, Michele D'Acosta and Nicholas Broomfield
results.brief_description: Flawed but intriguing documentary from Nick Broomfield, about the deaths of rival African American rappers, Tupac Shakur and Biggie Smalls. Tupac Shakur was born into an impoverished and fractured family life, but went on to become a hugely successful musician; Biggie Smalls came from less humble beginnings but was similarly successful in his field. Once close friends, these two became bitter rivals in a gang war between rappers and their entourages on the East and West coasts. By interviewing a slew of the pair’s contemporaries, including Biggie’s mother, Broomfield investigates the possibility that Death Records impresario Suge Knight murdered the two and that the LA police were complicit. Broomfield certainly stumbles where angels fear to tread, including a visit to prison to interview Knight, as well as filming some very agitated characters, presenting an ambivalent but fascinating portrait for the viewer to draw on.

results.title: Big Wednesday
results.creator_credit: A-Team Productions, Buzz Feitshans and John Milius
results.brief_description: Set between 1962 and 1974, “Big Wednesday” is the story of three surfing friends - Matt, Jack and Leroy. We see their loves, fights and the hero worship that follows them as they conquer the waves. The South Swell 1962: the three rule the waves. Together with their friends they get drunk, go on surfing holidays and have wild and destructive parties. As the years pass, the Vietnam War and growing up take their toll. They witness the changes in themselves, their home and friends. The Great Swell 1974: Matt, Jack and Leroy re-unite to brave one last journey together, to surf the great swell. “Big Wednesday” encapsulates the emotions of passing youth against the splendour of the sea and surfing. Includes a special appearance by surfing legend, “Mr. Pipeline”, Jerry Lopez. Cast includes: William Katt, Gary Busey, Jan Michael Vincent, Patti D’Arbanville and Lee Purcell.

results.title: Big night
results.creator_credit: Timpano Productions, Rysher Entertainment, Jonathan Filley, Campbell Scott and Stanley Tucci
results.brief_description: A treat for movie and food lovers everywhere, this multi-award winning comedy tells the story of two Italian brothers (Primo and Secondo), whose superb restaurant is on the brink of bankruptcy. Their only chance is to risk everything they own on one big night where they invite local identities and band leader Louis Prima to a six course, twenty-two dish feast that will either make or break them. Cast includes Ian Holm, Tony Shalhoub, Stanley Tucci, Isabella Rossellini and Minnie Driver.

results.title: Big (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Gracie Films, Robert Greenhut, James L. Brooks and Penny Marshall
results.brief_description: The wonderfully versatile Tom Hanks stars as Josh Baskin, a 12 year old who is transformed overnight into a 35 year old man when his wish to be ‘big’ comes true. Confused and frightened, Josh runs away to New York, where, by sheer luck, he lands the perfect job in a toy company. Suddenly he’s got freedom, money, toys and all the junk food he can eat. But he’s not prepared for what happens next when a sexy co-worker falls in love with him! Also stars Elizabeth Perkins and Robert Loggia.

results.title: Bicentennial man
results.creator_credit: Columbia Pictures, Touchstone Pictures, 1492 Pictures, Laurence Mark Productions, Radiant Productions, Wolfgang Petersen, Gail Katz, Neal E. Miller, Mark Radcliffe, Chris Columbus and Michael Barnathan
results.brief_description: Starring Robin Williams and Sam Neill, this is a futuristic tale set in the not so distant future when every home will have an NDR-114 robot - the latest technological advancement to serve man. This is the story of one NDR-114 robot, who came off the production line with a unique fault - he doesn’t want to be a robot, and his amazing 200-year journey to become human. Based on the short story and novel “The Positronic man” by Isaac Asimov.

results.title: Bhowani Junction
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Pandro S. Berman and George Cukor
results.brief_description: In what is considered by many fans to be her best performance, Ava Gardner stars as the half-caste heroine Victoria Jones, a woman forced to make some painful life decisions in post Colonial India. Her relationship with three men; Colonel Savage (Stewart Granger) a British military man in charge of protecting trains crossing Bhowani Junction, fellow Anglo-Indian Patrick Taylor (Bill Travers), and Sikh communist Peter Illing who befriends Victoria after she kills a potential rapist in self defence - challenging her to assess where her loyalties and ethnicity lie. Adapted from the novel by John Masters.

results.title: Beyond therapy
results.creator_credit: New World Pictures, Roger Berlind, Sandcastle 5, Steven Haft and Robert Altman
results.brief_description: Prudence (Julie Hagerty) is a conservative and slightly mixed-up young woman who thinks Bruce (Jeff Goldblum) is crazy. Bruce is crazy about Prudence, despite the fact that he is bisexual. Their therapists are no better off. Prudence’s therapist (Tom Conti) is more interested in scoring with his female patients than in treating their problems. Bruce’s therapist is as flighty as they come. Throw in Bruce’s jealous lover Bob (Christopher Guest), and his overly protective mother, and the scene is set for madness and mayhem. Adapted from his Broadway play by screenwriter Christopher Durang.
